hints_html:
What does the symbols

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2}\end{aligned}\]

mean in plain English?

Recall that when computing a partial derivative with respect to the variable y, you have to treat the variable x as if it was a constant, so for example the partial derivative of xy with respect to the variable y is simply x the same way that the derivative of 3y with respect to y would be 3.
hints_latex:
Recall that when computing a partial derivative with respect to the
variable \emph{y}, you have to treat the variable \emph{x} as if it was
a constant, so for example the partial derivative of \emph{xy} with
respect to the variable \emph{y} is simply \emph{x} the same way that
the derivative of \emph{3y} with respect to \emph{y} would be 3.
hints_raw:
What does the symbols
:<math> \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2}</math>
mean in plain English?
Recall that when computing a partial derivative with respect to the variable ''y'', you have to treat the variable ''x'' as if it was a constant, so for example the partial derivative of ''xy'' with respect to the variable ''y'' is simply ''x'' the same way that the derivative of ''3y'' with respect to ''y'' would be 3.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
We are asked here to compute the second derivative of the given function with respect to y. So we start by taking the first derivative with respect to y and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x,y) = 2x e^{2y} + 2y\end{aligned}\]

(Remember that while doing this, we treat the variable x as if it was a constant). And now we go on for the second derivative with respect to y and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2} (x,y) = \frac{\partial }{\partial y}\left( \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x,y) \right) = 4x e^{2y} + 2\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We are asked here to compute the second derivative of the given function
with respect to \emph{y}. So we start by taking the first derivative
with respect to \emph{y} and obtain

\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x,y) = 2x e^{2y} + 2y
\end{align*} (Remember that
while doing this, we treat the variable \emph{x} as if it was a
constant). And now we go on for the second derivative with respect to
\emph{y} and obtain

\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2} (x,y) = \frac{\partial }{\partial y}\left( \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x,y) \right) = 4x e^{2y} + 2
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We are asked here to compute the second derivative of the given function with respect to ''y''. So we start by taking the first derivative with respect to ''y'' and obtain
:<math>\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x,y) = 2x e^{2y} + 2y </math>
(Remember that while doing this, we treat the variable ''x'' as if it was a constant). And now we go on for the second derivative with respect to ''y'' and obtain
:<math>\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2} (x,y) = \frac{\partial }{\partial y}\left( \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x,y) \right) = 4x e^{2y} + 2</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x,y) = xe^{2y} + y^2\end{aligned}\]

Evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Let
:<math> \displaystyle f(x,y) = xe^{2y} + y^2</math>
Evaluate
:<math> \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2}</math>
